Effect of incorporation manner of Zr on the Co/SBA-15 catalyst for the Fischer–Tropsch synthesis Zhuo Li a b Jinhu Wu b ⁎ Jianqiang Yu a Dezhi Han b Liyang Wu b Jianqing Li b a School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Collaborative Innovation Center for Marine Biomass Fiber Materials and Textiles of Shandong Province, Qingdao University, 308 Ningxia Road, Qingdao 266071, PR China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Collaborative Innovation Center for Marine Biomass Fiber Materials and Textiles of Shandong Province Qingdao University 308 Ningxia Road Qingdao 266071 PR China b Key Laboratory of Biofuels, Qingdao Institute of Bioenergy and Bioprocess Technology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Qingdao 266101, PR China Key Laboratory of Biofuels Qingdao Institute of Bioenergy and Bioprocess Technology Chinese Academy of Sciences Qingdao 266101 PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract The effect of incorporation manner of Zr on the textural properties, surface physicochemical properties, reduction degree and catalytic performance of Co/SBA-15 catalyst for the Fischer–Tropsch synthesis (FTS) was investigated. The catalysts were prepared by sequential impregnation, co-impregnation and in-situ synthesis method, respectively. The loading amount of Co and Zr remained constant in all catalysts with 15wt.% and 5wt.%, respectively. The catalysts were characterized by N2 adsorption–desorption, X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), temperature-programmed reduction (H2 -TPR) and evaluated for the FTS. It was revealed that the Co3O4 was considered as the main surface cobalt phase, and the BET surface area and pore size were decreased regardless of the incorporation manner. The reduction degree of cobalt species increased from 80% (Co/SBA-15) to 90% (Co/Zr/SBA-15) and 85% (CoZr/SBA-15) with the addition of Zr, except for the Co/Zr-SBA-15 catalyst (74%). The catalyst prepared by sequential impregnation method (Co/Zr/SBA-15) showed the highest selectivity of long-chain hydrocarbons (C12–C22, 53%) with the chain growth probability α up to 0.84, which could be attributed to the highest reducibility of cobalt species. Keywords Fischer–Tropsch synthesis Co/SBA-15 Zirconium Hydrocarbons selectivity Chain growth probability 1 Introduction The Fischer–Tropsch synthesis (FTS) is a process that converts a mixture of carbon monoxide and hydrogen (also known as syngas) into clean liquid fuels or valuable chemicals [1,2]. Compared with the refinery diesel, the predominantly linear paraffinic hydrocarbons along with virtually no contaminants such as sulphur, nitrogen and aromatics in the FTS show a higher cetane number and lower pollutant emission level [2]. FTS has sparked renewed interest in utilization of nonpetroleum carbon resources (such as natural gas, coal and biomass) in recent years because of the increasingly stringent environmental regulations and the depletion of light and sweet petroleum reserves. Extensive researches on the FTS catalysts based on Ru, Co and Fe have been reported [1,3–5]. The high cost and low availability of Ru-based catalysts are important concerns limiting their commercial application. Compared to Fe-based catalyst, Co-based catalysts for FTS are usually preferred under carefully selected temperature and H2/CO ratio, and show higher selectivity in linear long-chain paraffin fractions, slower deactivation by water (a by-product of the FTS reaction), less oxygenates and lower CO2 selectivity [6–8]. Thus, the Co-based catalysts have attracted much attention for the synthesis of wax and liquid-fuel, while the Fe-based catalysts are suitable for the production of alkenes and oxygenate chemicals. Generally, the products of FTS follow the Anderson–Schultz–Flory (ASF) distribution due to the polymerization mechanism. Thus, the liquid fuels (mainly gasoline and diesel fuel) are usually obtained by the catalytic cracking process after FTS [9,10]. Recently, several studies have succeeded in the direct production of middle isoparaffins (C5–C12) or C10–C20 hydrocarbons with high selectivity [1,11,12]. It is generally accepted that the activity of Co-based catalysts for FTS is proportional to the density of surface active Co0. Therefore, Co species should be both highly dispersed and reduced on the catalyst surface [2,11]. For this reason, Co is commonly deposited on high surface area supports such as SiO2, Al2O3 and TiO2, probably the most extensively used for Co-based FTS catalysts. In the last decades, other alternative supports with mesoporous silicas have also been explored to provide new possibilities for tuning the products selectivity [13,14]. In particular, the SBA-15 with high surface area and narrow pore diameter distribution allows for high Co dispersion even at high metal loadings and can realize spatial confinement on the metal particle size to restrict the formation of hydrocarbons longer than some characteristic size (say, carbon number n <20) [9]. The addition of promoters, such as noble metals (Ru, Re) [8,15,16], transition metal oxides (ZrO2 and MnOx) [3,17,18] and some rare earth metal oxides (CaO, La2O3) [18,19] are capable of modifying the catalyst structure and improving the catalytic performance by enhancing the dispersion and reduction degree of cobalt species. A number of investigations have been focused on Zr-promoted Co catalysts, which exhibited higher CO conversion and C5+ selectivity for FTS than the un-promoted catalysts. Ali et al. [20] reported that the weaker Co–Zr interaction created an active interface that increased activity by favoring CO dissociation. Andreas and Moradi et al. [21,22] ascribed the increased activity to the easy reduction of cobalt species with the addition of Zr. Rohr et al. [23] concluded that the addition of ZrO2 to Co/Al2O3 catalyst increased the activity and selectivity to heavy hydrocarbons, while reducibility and dispersion have not been improved. Therefore, it is necessary to clarify the influence of Zr on the catalysts textural properties, surface physicochemical properties, reduction degree and catalytic performance for FTS reaction. In the present contribution, the 15wt.% Co/SBA-15 catalysts with 5wt.% Zr promotion were prepared in three different manners to provide the insight into the Zr modification on properties and product distributions of the catalysts. These catalysts were characterized by means of N2 adsorption–desorption, X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) as well as temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) to elucidate the Co–Zr interaction, dispersion and reducibility of Co species. And the catalytic performances of the catalysts were tested in FTS by using a fixed bed reactor. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The detailed preparation of SBA-15 can be found in elsewhere [9]. Co/SBA-15 catalyst was prepared by incipient wet impregnation of the SBA-15 support with a desired amount of cobalt(II) nitrate dissolved in water in equal with respect to the pore volume of the SBA-15 support. The precursor were dried at 120°C and calcined at 400°C for 4h. The loading amount of Co in the final catalyst was 15wt.%. Co/Zr/SBA-15 was prepared by sequentially impregnated method. Typically, the SBA-15 support was firstly impregnated with a desired amount of aqueous zirconium (IV) nitrate. After dried at 120°C and calcined at 400°C for 4h, the Zr/SBA-15 was obtained. Then it was impregnated with the aqueous of cobalt(II) nitrate followed by drying at 120°C and calcination at 400°C for 4h. The loading amount of Zr and Co in the final catalyst was 5wt.% and 15wt.%, respectively, which were reported by Mu et al. for the maximum CO conversion and C5+ selectivity in the FTS [24]. CoZr/SBA-15 was prepared by co-impregnated method. The SBA-15 support was impregnated with a desired amount of zirconium(IV) nitrate and cobalt(II) nitrate dissolved in water in equal with respect to the pore volume of the SBA-15 support. Then it was dried at 120°C and calcined at 400°C for 4h. The loading amount of Zr and Co in the final catalysts was the same as Co/Zr/SBA-15. Zr-SBA-15 was synthesized in-situ as follows: P123 (EO20PO70EO20, MAV=5800, Aldrich) was dissolved in 2M HCl with stirring to obtain a clear solution. TEOS (Aldrich) and ZrOCl2·8H2O were gradually added into the solution with continuous stirring for 24h. The mixture was hydrothermally treated to crystallize in a Teflon-lined autoclave at 120°C for 24h followed by filtering, washing and drying at 120°C. Calcination of the dried cake was then carried out in an electric oven in air at 400°C for 6h. Finally, the Co/Zr-SBA-15 was prepared by incipient wet impregnation method as the same preparation procedure of Co/SBA-15. The loading amount of Zr and Co was the same as Co/Zr/SBA-15. All the chemicals were supplied by Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. China and used as received. 2.2 Catalyst characterization Nitrogen adsorption–desorption were measured on an ASAP 2010 Micromeritics to determine the BET surface area and porosity. Prior to the measurements, the samples were degassed at 300°C for 5h. Nitrogen isotherms were obtained in both adsorption and desorption modes. The surface area was determined by the BET method and the pore volume was calculated from the amount of vapor adsorbed at a relative pressure of 0.995. Pore size were established from the desorption branches of the isotherms using the Barret-Joyner-Halender (BJH) method [13]. X-ray diffraction patterns of the catalysts were collected on a Brukers D8 powder diffractometer with Cu-Kα radiation at a rate of 4°min−1 in the range 2θ=0°–70°. The average crystallite size of Co3O4 (d(Co3O4)) was calculated from the Scherrer equation d(Co3O4)=Kλ/T cosθ at the most intense reflexion 2θ=36.9° [25,26], where K is a constant near unity, and T is the average thickness of the crystal. The Co3O4 crystallite sizes in the samples were then converted to the corresponding cobalt metal diameters in reduced catalyst using the equation: d(Co0)=0.75×d(Co3O4) [27]. The Co0 metal dispersions could be calculated using D=96/d(Co0), assuming a spherical geometry of the metal particles with uniform site density of 14.6atoms/nm2, Where D is the% dispersion and d is the average crystallite size of Co0 in nm [1]. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed on a Physical Electronics Company Quantum-2000 Scaning ESCA Microprobe spectrometer. The Al-Kα non-monochromatized line (1486.6eV) of a twin anode in the constant analyzer energy mode with a pass energy of 50eV was used. In order to remove charging shifts and deal with Fermi edge coupling problems, the C 1s (284.6eV) were used to revise all the binding energies (BEs). The morphology of the catalyst samples was measured using scanning electron microscopy (SEM) with a Hitachi S-4800 microscope operated at 10kV. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) measurements were performed on a H-7650 electron microscope operated at an acceleration voltage of 100kV. The reduction behaviour of the samples was performed by temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) in a U-tube quartz cell. Firstly, about 100mg of the calcined catalyst was purged with Ar (40mLmin−1) at 300°C for 1h and cooled to 50°C. After that, it was exposed to 10vol% H2/Ar (40mLmin−1) with the temperature from 100°C to 800°C at a ramp rate of 10°Cmin−1. A different set of experiments was performed in the same equipment to determine the reduction degree of cobalt oxides. About 100mg of calcined catalyst was loaded into the U-tube quartz cell and reduced in-situ at 450°C for 6h at a heating rate of 1°Cmin−1 in the 10vol% H2/Ar (40mLmin−1). The H2 consumption amount was monitored with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and corrected by the CuO reduction. The reduction degree was calculated on the amount of H2 consumed during the reduction treatment at 450°C divided by stoichiometric amounts of H2 required for the complete reduction of cobalt oxides. 2.3 Catalytic performance test The FTS reaction was performed in a pressured fixed-bed reactor (dint =8mm, l=40cm) at 2MPa, 240°C and space velocity (GHSV) of 1000h−1. Typically, a catalyst of ∼1.5mL was mixed with 1.5mL of quartz particles and charged into the reactor to form a diluted catalyst bed. The catalyst was initially reduced at 450°C for 6h in a H2 stream (50mLmin−1). After the temperature declined to 100°C, the reactant gas mixture composed of H2/CO/N2 =6/3/1 (v/v) was introduced into the reactor and the reaction was led to proceed during a period of 24h to ensure stabilization of the catalyst activity. The gas effluent was analysed on-line using an Agilent 7890 chromatograph and another gas chromatograph (Agilent 7820A) was used to analyse the composition of the liquid products, which was collected by a hot trap and a cold trap. Each experimental run was repeated at least three times and the mass balance estimated as a means of confirming the validity of the experimental runs was >90%. Preliminary experiments were performed in the absence of catalyst, which showed that the FTS reaction was negligible under the reaction conditions. The turnover frequencies (TOFs) were calculated by normalizing the CO reaction rate by the number of surface active Co sites. CO conversion must maintained 5%–10% to ensure that intrinsic rate data was obtained free of heat and mass transfer effects [28]. Thus, ∼0.3mL catalyst and 2.0mL of quartz particles was charged into the reactor under the reaction conditions of 2MPa, 240°C and space velocity (GHSV) of 10000–18000h−1. Meanwhile, the CO conversion was based on the initial activity of fresh catalyst and measured after reaching a near steady-state condition, i.e., within 2–3h after the beginning of the run. The surface number of active sites was based on the total amount of Co3O4 in the catalyst and its reduction degree during the pre-reduction step, as well as the dispersion of Co. The concrete equation is as follows: T O F = the CO reaction rate the surface number of active Co sites = X ( CO ) * Q/22.4/60 ( m * x * D * R ) / M In the expression, X(CO) is the CO conversion, Q is the flow rate of CO at the reactor inlet (Lmin−1),m is the weight of catalyst, x is the loading of Co in the catalyst, D is the dispersion of Co calculated from the XRD characterization, R is the reduction degree of Co species calculated from the H2-TPR and M is the molar weight of Co atom. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Textural properties of catalysts The N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms for the SBA-15 and Zr-SBA-15 support presented the hysteresis condensation and evaporation steps characteristic of type H1 at the P/P0 range of 0.65–0.85 according to the IUPAC classification, indicating the periodic mesoporous structure (Fig. 1 a) [2]. However, the addition of Co and/or Zr produces a hysteresis characteristic of type H4 at the P/P0 range of 0.4–1.0 without an obvious platform of adsorption saturation (Fig. 1b). The gas uptake at the P/P0 range of 0.4–0.8 corresponded to the adsorption in mesopores and on external surface [29], and the gas uptake occurred between 0.8-1.0 were typical for micropores. That revealed the presence of micropores besides the mesopores of support after the addition of Co and/or Zr, which may be caused by a partial blockage located at the entrance and/or inside the pores or a partial collapse of the mesoporous structure [16]. Correspondingly, the mean pore size determined using the BJH method and the total pore volume were both decreased, as given in Table 1 . In addition, the initial uptakes for all catalysts with the incorporation of Co and Zr were lower than that of the SBA-15 support, indicating lower BET surface areas (as listed in Table 1). A dilution effect could be invoked in all cases. However, it did not account for the totality of the reduction observed. A dilution effect would produce a maximum 20% reduction, while the actual reduction was more than 50% [2]. The partial plugging and collapse of the pores, as well as the external surface coverage by the Co and/or Zr oxides during impregnation/calcination could account for the higher loss of BET surface area observed. This was also supported by the fact that a more decrease of the BET surface area of Co/Zr/SBA-15 catalyst was observed than that of the CoZr/SBA-15 catalyst with one less time impregnation and calcination. 3.2 Crystalline phase and morphology of catalysts As shown in Fig. 2 , the well-defined reflection characteristics at 18.9°, 31.3°, 36.9°, 44.8°, 59.4° and 65.2° for the Co/SBA-15 and Zr promoted catalysts indicated the presence of crystalline cobalt species of Co3O4 spinel [9]. Meanwhile, the reflections of 2θ=0°–2.5° and 10°–40° were taken as evidence of the presence of SBA-15. However, the absence of peaks related to Zr phase implied the presence of XRD silent-crystallites due to low loading or high dispersion rather than a separate bulk phase, regardless of the incorporation manner. The average crystallite sizes of Co3O4 was estimated from the Scherrer equation based on the peak of 2θ=36.9° in the XRD patterns. While such estimation was subjected to significant errors owing to the assumption, it was useful for comparison purpose. It was shown that the Co/SBA-15 and Zr promoted catalysts with different incorporation manners had an average Co3O4 crystallite sizes of 14±1nm and the Co0 dispersion of 7±1% (as shown in Table 1), which were not consistent with the previous works. Ali et al. [20] found that the Co3O4 crystallite sizes were smaller for the Zr promoted Co/SiO2 catalyst by co-impregnation than that by sequential impregnation, and Jacobs et al. [30] reported that the modification of the support with Zr could enhance the Co0 dispersion. The differences might arise from the Co loading (15wt.% vs. 20wt.%), the calcination conditions (400°C for 4h vs. 300°C for 2h) and the support (SBA-15 vs. SiO2). It must be noted that the Co3O4 crystallite sizes (14±1nm) was larger than the average pore diameter of the SBA-15 and Zr-SBA-15 supports (9.1nm and 8.0nm, see Table 1), which indicated that the Co3O4 particles were located either on the external surface or at the pore entrance of the supports. This was in accordance with the explanation of the decrease of specific surface area and mean pore size, as well as pore volume. 3.3 Morphology of catalysts The morphologies of the catalysts (in Fig. 3 ) revealed that the Co/SBA-15, Co/Zr/SBA-15 and CoZr/SBA-15 showed a similar fibrous structure with small rod-like sub-particles 1–2μm in length and 0.5μm in diameter, which was in agreement with the report of Katiyar et al. [31]. While the sub-particles of Co/Zr-SBA-15 were larger (2–3μm in length and 1μm in diameter) than the others, which might be due to the addition of Zr in the synthesis of SBA-15 [32]. It could be directly observed from Fig. 4 that SBA-15 had a highly ordered arrangement of the channels and the darker contrasts were representative of Co3O4 located either on the external surface or within the channels. It was revealed that the Co3O4 was located both on the external surface and within the channels of SBA-15 (Fig. 4a), whereas all of the Co3O4 was regarded as on the external surface of Zr-SBA-15 (Fig. 4b). Meanwhile, it was noticed that most cobalt particles were confined inside the SBA-15 channels in the case of the Co/Zr/SBA-15 and CoZr/SBA-15 catalysts (Fig. 4c and d). 3.4 XPS characterization of catalysts Fig. 5 shows the XPS narrow scan spectra for the Co 2p1/2 and Co 2p3/2 peaks featured at the binding energy (BE) of 780.1–780.3eV and 795.0–795.6eV, which were typical for Co2+ and Co3+ in the Co3O4 spinel phase [33]. Furthermore, for all catalysts the doublet separation of the binding energy (ΔE) between the Co 2p1/2 and Co 2p3/2 peaks was 14.8–15.3eV, which was close to that of the mixed-valence Co3O4 (15.2eV) [34]. Therefore, Co3O4 was considered as the main surface cobalt phase in these catalysts after calcination, which was in agreement with the XRD results. Moreover, the satellite peaks located at 803.4–804.0eV and 783.7–788.0eV confirmed the existence of Co2+ species in octahedral symmetry as found in CoO [16,35]. Peak deconvolution and fitting to experimental data showed that the Co 2p peak could be fitted well by six peaks (dotted curves), corresponding to the chemical states of Co2+ satellite, Co2+ and Co3+ (see Table 2 and Fig. 5). It was noted that the catalysts exhibited a remarkably higher ratio of Co2+ to Co3+ with respect to Co3O4 (the Co2+/Co3+ ratio was 0.5 in Co3O4), which indicated that the Co2+ species existed in the state of CoO or Co3O4 particles were in intimate contact with the Si oxides of the support [33]. In the case of the Co/Zr-SBA-15 and Co/Zr/SBA-15 catalysts, the lower ratio of Co2+/Co3+ (2.7 and 3.0) than that (3.6) of the Co/SBA-15 catalyst was an solid evidence of the lower content of surface CoO. However, the lowest ratio of Co2+/Co3+ (1.2) for the CoZr/SBA-15 catalyst pointed to the formation of cobalt zirconium solid solution, which would be revealed in Section 3.5, although not detectable by XRD. 3.5 Reducibility of Co species in the catalysts H2-TPR profiles have been normalized per weight of cobalt in the Co/SBA-15 and Zr promoted catalysts to facilitate the discussion on the reduction behaviour of Co3O4 (shown in Fig. 6 ). Three reduction peaks were observed for all the catalysts. The reduction of Co3O4 to CoO (Peak I) happened quickly, resulting in a sharp low-temperature peak. The reduction of CoO to Co0 (peak II) proceeded slowly to form a broad profile, which demonstrated the existence of different CoO species with various reduction temperatures, further which was consistent with the XPS results. This was also confirmed by the higher H2 consumption ratio of peak II to peak I (based on the peak fitting), as the stoichiometric ratio being 3/1 in Co3O4 (listed in Table 3 ). The Zr-SBA-15 support also facilitated the formation of CoO species with a much more broad profile of peak II, which seemed to be contrary to the XPS results. Note that the escape depth of photoelectrons generated during the XPS analysis was less than 10nm. Meanwhile, the intense and sharp peak III (above 600°C) in the case of Co/Zr/SBA-15 and CoZr/SBA-15 catalyst could be explained in terms of the possible formation of solid solution between Co and Zr, as previously reported by Bartolini et al. [2]. As expected, the reduction degree of Co species increased from 80% (Co/SBA-15) to 90% (Co/Zr/SBA-15) and 85% (CoZr/SBA-15) with the addition of Zr, except for the Co/Zr-SBA-15 catalyst (74%). It was confirmed that the addition of Zr by sequential impregnation and co-impregnation method could increase the Co reducibility by reducing the interaction between Co and SBA-15 with somewhat weaker Co-ZrO2 interaction [22,36,37], which was also benefited to the high catalytic activity [17]. 3.6 Performance of the catalysts in Fischer–Tropsch synthesis The FTS performance of cobalt-based catalysts with different incorporation manner of Zr were tested in a fixed bed reactor. It can be seen from Table 4 that no significant differences were observed in terms of CO conversion for the catalysts except for Co/Zr-SBA-15. Indeed, an increased turnover frequency (TOF) was observed with the addition of Zr irrespective of the incorporation manner, with the highest TOF on Co/Zr/SBA-15 catalyst. The introduction of Zr might create an active interface with Co that was responsible to some extent for the enhancement in Co activity by facilitating the CO dissociation, which was agreement with the report of Borer and Xiong et al. [17,38]. It also can be seen from Table 4 that the Co/Zr-SBA-15 catalyst showed a higher selectivity toward CH4 (28%) and C2–C4 hydrocarbons (17%), as well as lower selectivity toward CO2 (3%) compared with Co/SBA-15. It was reported that the high CH4 selectivity was ascribed to the presence of either unreduced cobalt species or to small cobalt particles, and the CO2 product was attributed to the water–gas shift reaction (WGS: CO+H2O=CO2 +H2). While the Co/Zr/SBA-15 and CoZr/SBA-15 catalysts presented the relatively low selectivity of CO2 and almost the same selectivity of CH4. It was also demonstrated that there was no direct relationship between the CH4 and the CO2 selectivity, which were in accordance with the report of Khodakov et al. [14]. It was demonstrated that the C5+ selectivity of the catalysts was enhanced about 10% with respect to the Co/Zr/SBA-15 and CoZr/SBA-15 catalyst (shown in Table 4), which could be ascribed to the interaction between the reaction intermediates and the Lewis acidity of ZrO2 [39]. The liquid hydrocarbons distribution (Table 4 and Fig. 7 ) revealed that the Co/Zr-SBA-15 and CoZr/SBA-15 catalyst exhibited an improved C5–C11 selectivity compared to the Co/SBA-15 catalyst. Meanwhile, the Co/Zr/SBA-15 facilitated the formation of long-chain hydrocarbons with the maximum selectivity (53%) of C12–C22. Correspondingly, the Co/Zr-SBA-15 catalyst with the highest light hydrocarbons (CH4 and C2–C4) selectivity was characterized by a chain growth probability (α) to 0.78, which was obtained from the slope of the ASF plots in the C5+ hydrocarbon range (shown in Fig. 8 ). Meanwhile, α=0.84 was achieved over the Co/Zr/SBA-15 catalyst with an increased selectivity toward long-chain hydrocarbons (C12–C22). A long-term study on the catalytic performance for each catalyst was performed, and the CO conversion, CH4 selectivity and C5+ selectivity as a function of time on stream for 100h were depicted in Fig. 9 . It was clearly noticed that the deactivation only occurred on the Co/SBA-15 catalyst after 50h with decreased CO conversion and C5+ selectivity, as well as increased CH4 selectivity. However, the catalytic parameters for the catalysts with Zr incorporation remained essentially constant for the whole test period, which indicated that the addition of Zr could promote the stability of the catalyst regardless of the incorporation manner. 4 Conclusions The characterizations revealed that Co3O4 was considered as the main surface cobalt phase, and the BET surface area and pore size were decreased for all the catalysts. The reduction degree of Co species increased from 80% (Co/SBA-15) to 90% (Co/Zr/SBA-15) and 85% (CoZr/SBA-15) due to the formation of somewhat Co-ZrO2 interaction, except for the Co/Zr-SBA-15 catalyst. The interaction between the reaction intermediates and the Lewis acidity of ZrO2 also enhanced the C5+ selectivity by about 10% with respect to the Co/Zr/SBA-15 and CoZr/SBA-15 catalyst. Especially, the Co/Zr/SBA-15 catalyst facilitated the formation of long-chain hydrocarbons (C12–C22, 53%). Furthermore, the addition of Zr also improved the turnover frequency (TOF) and promoted the stability of the catalyst regardless of the incorporation manner. coredata.dc:description: The effect of incorporation manner of Zr on the textural properties, surface physicochemical properties, reduction degree and catalytic performance of Co/SBA-15 catalyst for the Fischer–Tropsch synthesis (FTS) was investigated. The catalysts were prepared by sequential impregnation, co-impregnation and in-situ synthesis method, respectively. The loading amount of Co and Zr remained constant in all catalysts with 15wt.% and 5wt.%, respectively. The catalysts were characterized by N2 adsorption–desorption, X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), temperature-programmed reduction (H2 -TPR) and evaluated for the FTS. It was revealed that the Co3O4 was considered as the main surface cobalt phase, and the BET surface area and pore size were decreased regardless of the incorporation manner. The reduction degree of cobalt species increased from 80% (Co/SBA-15) to 90% (Co/Zr/SBA-15) and 85% (CoZr/SBA-15) with the addition of Zr, except for the Co/Zr-SBA-15 catalyst (74%). The catalyst prepared by sequential impregnation method (Co/Zr/SBA-15) showed the highest selectivity of long-chain hydrocarbons (C12–C22, 53%) with the chain growth probability α up to 0.84, which could be attributed to the highest reducibility of cobalt species.
coredata.dc:title: Effect of incorporation manner of Zr on the Co/SBA-15 catalyst for the Fischer–Tropsch synthesis
coredata.prism:publicationName: Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical
